page.title: 05Hobson's Conduit
page.content: Thomas Hobson was a 17th century gentleman who ran a horse service between Cambridge and London for a living. If you hired one of his horses you would not have a choice but had to take the next one that was ready-hence the saying 'Hobson's Choice'- meaning none! A notice by the front of the Conduit in Lensfield Rd reads "This structure stood upon the market hill and served as a conduit from 1614 to 1856 in which year it was erected on this spot by public subscription." It also tells that the water comes from Great Shelford. On the back it reads "Thomas Hobson, carrier between Cambridge and London and a great ben- efactor to his town. Died 1st day of January in the 86th year of his age". He founded almshouses and gave money to educate poor children as well as giving Cambridge a good water supply.
